meanings.def: with no or very little light, especially because it is night
examples: a dark room/street/forest/night
What time does it get dark in summer?
Then the theatre went dark.
It was dark outside and I couldn't see much.
The sky was still dark.
Use lights to illuminate dark corners.
It gets dark at about six o'clock.
As it grew dark, they gathered round the fire.
It's only three o'clock and it's nearly dark already.
They stepped into the dark room and shone the torch.
He stumbled along through the dark forest.

meanings.def: not light; closer in shade to black than to white
examples: dark blue/green/red/brown
Darker colours are more practical and don't show stains.

meanings.def: having a colour that is close to black
examples: He wore a dark suit and a plain tie.
dark-coloured wood
The dark clouds in the sky meant that a storm was coming.
Sue has long dark hair.
He was handsome with dark eyes.
Even if you have dark skin, you still need protection from the sun.
a dark handsome stranger

meanings.def: mysterious; hidden and not known about
examples: There are no dark secrets in our family.
There was a darker side to his nature.
the dark forces of the imagination
My mind was full of dark thoughts.

meanings.def: unpleasant and without any hope that something good will happen
examples: the darkest days of Fascism
The film is a dark vision of the future.
The theatre stayed open even in the darkest days of the war.

meanings.def: produced with the back part of the tongue close to the back of the mouth. In many accents of (= ways of pronouncing) English, dark /l/ is used after a vowel, as in ball.
a person who does not tell other people much about their life, and who surprises other people by having interesting qualities
a person taking part in a race, etc. who surprises everyone by winning
to keep something secret and not tell people about it
examples: He’s got two children? Well he’s kept that dark, hasn’t he!

idioms.def: a person who does not tell other people much about their life, and who surprises other people by having interesting qualities
to keep something secret and not tell people about it
examples: He’s got two children? Well he’s kept that dark, hasn’t he!

related: be in a good, bad, dark, etc. space

meanings.def: the lack of light in a place, especially because it is night
examples: Are the children afraid of the dark?
in the dark All the lights went out and we were left in the dark.
animals that can see in the dark
The armbands glow in the dark.
I fumbled for the light switch in the pitch dark.
I hate getting up in the dark.
We could just make out some figures in the gathering dark.

meanings.def: an amount of something that is dark in colour
examples: patterns of light and dark

meanings.def: after/before the sun goes down and it is night
examples: Try to get home before dark.
Don't go out alone after dark.
Workers were kept in the dark about the plans to sell the company.
She arrived at the meeting as much in the dark as everyone else.

meanings.def: an action or a risk that you take without knowing anything about the activity or what the result will be
examples: I didn’t know what the new job would be like—I just took a leap in the dark.

meanings.def: a guess; something you do without knowing what the result will be
examples: The figure he came up with was really just a shot in the dark.
It was only a stab in the dark, but I hoped I could learn something.

meanings.def: to pretend not to be afraid
examples: Instead of whistling in the dark about the inevitable disaster, we should be making plans for when it strikes.

idioms.def: after/before the sun goes down and it is night
examples: Try to get home before dark.
Don't go out alone after dark.
Workers were kept in the dark about the plans to sell the company.
She arrived at the meeting as much in the dark as everyone else.

idioms.def: an action or a risk that you take without knowing anything about the activity or what the result will be
examples: I didn’t know what the new job would be like—I just took a leap in the dark.

idioms.def: a guess; something you do without knowing what the result will be
examples: The figure he came up with was really just a shot in the dark.
It was only a stab in the dark, but I hoped I could learn something.

idioms.def: to pretend not to be afraid
examples: Instead of whistling in the dark about the inevitable disaster, we should be making plans for when it strikes.
